elements.content: The reaction of the deprotonated N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-valine ligand (“Sval”) with Cu(II) salts afforded [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)3] n , 1, which has a 1D coordination polymeric structure cross-linked by strong hydrogen bonds to give 2D hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer in the solid state. Compound 1 can lose all the water molecules bonded to Cu(II) below 110 °C. However, recrystallization from aqueous solution of anhydrous 1 gave a supramolecular isomer, [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ·2nH2O, 2. Interestingly, the thermal dehydration behavior of 2 is very similar to that of 1. Pseudo-supramolecular isomeric compounds of [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ·0.5nC3H7OH, 3, and [Cu4(Sval)4(H2O)2(C4H9OH)] n ·nC4H9OH, 4, were obtained when anhydrous 1 was recrystallized from 2-proponal and 1-butanol, respectively.

Compound 1 can lose all the water molecules bonded to Cu(II) below 110 °C. However, recrystallization from aqueous solution of anhydrous 1 gave a supramolecular isomer, [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ⋅2nH2O, 2. Interestingly, the thermal dehydration behavior of 2 is very similar to that of 1. Pseudo-supramolecular isomeric compounds of [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ⋅0.5nC3H7OH, 3, and [Cu4(Sval)4(H2O)2(C4H9OH)] n ⋅nC4H9OH, 4, were obtained when anhydrous 1 was recrystallized from 2-proponal and 1-butanol, respectively.

elements.content: The solid-state structures of four 1D coordination polymers of Cu(II) with N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-valine have been described. Of these, two are supramolecular isomers and the other two are examples of pseudo-supramolecular isomers.
elements.clean_text: The solid-state structures of four 1D coordination polymers of Cu(II) with N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-valine have been described. Of these, two are supramolecular isomers and the other two are examples of pseudo-supramolecular isomers.

elements.content: Organic crystal engineering is mainly concerned with the assembly of molecules via non covalent interactions, while inorganic crystal engineering has an additional tool to assemble molecules, namely, through coordination bonds. Although the coordinate bonds are much stronger than the noncovalent bonds, they can easily be broken and reassembled in solution, if the metal−ligand combination used is highly labile. Further magnetic, optical, and catalytic properties are accessible by incorporating metals in the molecular assembly. Hydrogen-bonded metal complexes or coordination polymers have the advantages of both coordination bonds and more predictable hydrogen bonds in constructing supramolecular structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Organic crystal engineering is mainly concerned with the assembly of molecules via non covalent interactions, while inorganic crystal engineering has an additional tool to assemble molecules, namely, through coordination bonds. Although the coordinate bonds are much stronger than the noncovalent bonds, they can easily be broken and reassembled in solution, if the metal-ligand combination used is highly labile. Further magnetic, optical, and catalytic properties are accessible by incorporating metals in the molecular assembly. Hydrogen-bonded metal complexes or coordination polymers have the advantages of both coordination bonds and more predictable hydrogen bonds in constructing supramolecular structures.

elements.content: We have been interested in the metal coordination polymeric structures using flexible multidentate ligands, namely, N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-amino acids. In addition to donor sites, these ligands have both hydrogen donor and acceptor functionalities to form hydrogen bonds. It is well-known that the conformationally flexible molecules are expected to exhibit polymorphism as well as supramolecular isomerism since the energies required to rotate the single bonds are comparable in magnitude to the lattice energy differences observed between polymorphs and supramolecular isomers. However, such isomers have not been encountered before for these reduced Schiff base ligands.
elements.clean_text: We have been interested in the metal coordination polymeric structures using flexible multidentate ligands, namely, N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-amino acids. In addition to donor sites, these ligands have both hydrogen donor and acceptor functionalities to form hydrogen bonds. It is well-known that the conformationally flexible molecules are expected to exhibit polymorphism as well as supramolecular isomerism since the energies required to rotate the single bonds are comparable in magnitude to the lattice energy differences observed between polymorphs and supramolecular isomers. However, such isomers have not been encountered before for these reduced Schiff base ligands.

elements.content: To study the steric influence of the side chain in the reduced Schiff base ligands on the crystal structures of the Cu(II) complexes, hydrogen-bond pattern, and intermolecular interactions, we have used the amino acid l-valine. Crystallization of the Cu(II) complexes of N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-valine (the ligand is shown in Figure and abbreviated as H2Sval) under different experimental conditions yielded four conformationally different 1D coordination polymers. Of these, two belong to supramolecular structural isomers, while the other two may be considered as pseudo-supramolecular structural isomers. The details are discussed in this paper.

elements.content: Synthesis of Ligands. H 2 Sval. To a solution of l-valine (10 mmol) in water (10 mL) containing KOH (56 mg, 10 mmol) was added salicyladehyde (120 mg, 10 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL). The yellow solution was stirred for 30 min at room temperature prior to cooling in ice bath. The intermediate Schiff base was reduced by an excess of sodium borohydride (46 mg, 12 mmol) solid. The yellow color discharged after a few minutes, and the solution was acidified by acetic acid to a pH of 5−6. The resulting solid was filtered off, washed with ethanol and then diethyl ether, and dried. Yield. 99 mg (49%); mp 225−227° C. Anal. Calcd for C12H17NO3 C, 64.57; H, 7.62; N, 6.28; found:  C, 64.32; H, 7.25; N, 6.49. 1H NMR (dmso-d 6):  δ 0.91(d, 6H, H10, H11), 2.00 (m, H, H9), 2.95 (d, H, H8) and 3.82 (AB system, 2H, J AB = 13.6 Hz, H7), 6.73−6.75 (m, 2H, H2, H5), 7.11−7.19 (m, 2H, H3, H4).

elements.content: Synthesis of Complexes. [Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ] n , 1. To a solution of H2Sval (208 mg, 1 mmol) and LiOH (28 mg, 2 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added copper(II) acetate monohydrate (200 mg, 1 mmol) in water (10 mL). The dark green solution was stirred for 10 min and filtered. Green long rodlike crystals formed form the filtrate in a few days. The crystals were separated by decantation and dried in air. Yield:  230 mg (37%); Anal. Calcd. for C24H36Cu2N2O9: C, 46.2; H, 5.8; N, 4.5. Found:  C, 45.7; H, 5.4; N, 4.4. UV−vis (Nujol, nm):  372 (CT) and 671(d−d transition). μB = 1.40 BM.

elements.content: Instrumentation. Microanalyses were performed by the Microanalysis Laboratory at the National University of Singapore. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrophotometer. The 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ACF 300 spectrometer at 300 MHz for solutions in DMSO-d 6 and D2O with SiMe4 as internal standard. The TG curves were recorded on a SDT 2980 TGA Thermal analyzer using a sample size of 6−8 mg and a heating rate of 10 °C/min per run.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out on a Bruker SMART 1000 diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector and a Mo−Kα sealed tube at 23 °C. SMART was used for collecting frames data, indexing reflection and determination of lattice parameters, SAINT8 was used for integration of intensity of reflections scaling. SADABS was used for adsorption correction and SHELXTL for space group and structure determination and least-squares refinements on F 2. All the C−H hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculated positions for the purpose of structure factor calculations. All the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 1−4 were located in Fourier difference maps. The isotropic thermal parameters and positional parameters of these hydrogen atoms in 2 and 3 have been refined, while those in 1 and 4 were fixed using the option DFIX in SHELXTL. The crystal data and selected refinement details are displayed in Table . Selected bond parameters for 1−4 are compiled in Table while selected hydrogen bond parameters are given in Table .

Light green needlelike single crystals of [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)3] n , 1, have been obtained by slow evaporation of the aqueous solution containing copper(II) acetate monohydrate and Sval dianion in the ratio of 1:1. Compound 1 was dehydrated by heating to 115−120 °C for 2 h or 150 °C for an hour. The anhydrous solid was redissolved in various solvents such as water, 2-propanol, and 1-butanol to grow the single crystals of the desired anhydrous complex. However, slow evaporation of the solution yielded the single crystals of [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ·2nH2O, 2; [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ·0.5nC3H7OH, 3; and [Cu4(Sval)4(H2O)2(C4H9OH)] n ·nC4H9OH, 4. Compounds 3 and 4 have been found to contain coordinated water molecules which might have come from the undistilled organic solvents or from moisture in the air since the crystallization was carried out in open atmosphere. All the four compounds have been characterized in the solid-state by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques.

Results and Discussion

Light green needlelike single crystals of [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)3] n , 1, have been obtained by slow evaporation of the aqueous solution containing copper(II) acetate monohydrate and Sval dianion in the ratio of 1:1. Compound 1 was dehydrated by heating to 115-120 °C for 2 h or 150 °C for an hour. The anhydrous solid was redissolved in various solvents such as water, 2-propanol, and 1-butanol to grow the single crystals of the desired anhydrous complex. However, slow evaporation of the solution yielded the single crystals of [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ⋅2nH2O, 2; [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ⋅0.5nC3H7OH, 3; and [Cu4(Sval)4(H2O)2(C4H9OH)] n ⋅nC4H9OH, 4. Compounds 3 and 4 have been found to contain coordinated water molecules which might have come from the undistilled organic solvents or from moisture in the air since the crystallization was carried out in open atmosphere. All the four compounds have been characterized in the solid-state by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ] n , 1. The complex [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)3] n crystallizes as an infinite one-dimensional coordination polymer that consists of dimeric repeating units as shown in Figure . Both Cu(II) centers have distorted octahedral geometry. The Cu−O and Cu−N distances are very similar to a number of dicopper(II) complexes with this chromophore reported in the literature. The fifth axial position at Cu1 is occupied by water molecule with Cu1−O7, 2.547(2) Å and the coordination geometry is completed by carboxylato O atom (Cu1−O3 [x − 1/2, 1/2 − y, 1 − z], 2.743(9) Å) from the adjacent dimer. Both axial positions of Cu2 are taken by two water molecules with Cu2−O8, 2.421(4) and Cu2−O9, 2.659(6) Å. The axial Cu−O distances are longer than normal covalent bond but less than the sum of the van der Waals radii, 2.9 Å; however, these bonds are represented as solid bonds in this paper.

The complex [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)3] n  crystallizes as an infinite one-dimensional coordination polymer that consists of dimeric repeating units as shown in Figure . Both Cu(II) centers have distorted octahedral geometry. The Cu-O and Cu-N distances are very similar to a number of dicopper(II) complexes with this chromophore reported in the literature. The fifth axial position at Cu1 is occupied by water molecule with Cu1-O7, 2.547(2) Å and the coordination geometry is completed by carboxylato O atom (Cu1-O3 [x - 1/2, 1/2 - y, 1 - z], 2.743(9) Å) from the adjacent dimer. Both axial positions of Cu2 are taken by two water molecules with Cu2-O8, 2.421(4) and Cu2-O9, 2.659(6) Å. The axial Cu-O distances are longer than normal covalent bond but less than the sum of the van der Waals radii, 2.9 Å; however, these bonds are represented as solid bonds in this paper.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O)] n ·2 n H 2 O, 2. The complex [Cu2(Sval)2(H2O)] n ·2nH2O, 2, also crystallizes as 1D infinite coordination polymer with dimeric repeating units (Figure ). The coordination geometry adopted by the Cu(II) centers may be best described as a 4+1 distorted square pyramid. The angular parameter, τ values 0.07 and 0.25 for Cu1 and Cu2, respectively, also support square pyramidal geometry in each case. The axial site at Cu1 is occupied by a water molecule, Cu1−O7, 2.310(4) Å; the other site forms a bridge to an adjacent dimer through a carboxylato O atom (Cu2−O3 (x, y − 1, z), 2.767(1) Å). The net result is a 1D polymer formed by carboxylate apically linked dimers (see Figure a) aligned along a-axis. A HOH···OCO hydrogen bond is present in each dimer as shown in Figure . The sixth positions at Cu(II) is vacant as there is no close interaction less than the sum of the van der Waals radii, 2.9 Å found. The extra two water molecules have been located in the lattice instead of bonded to Cu(II) ions as in 1. The relative conformations of the dimeric repeating units in the 1D coordination polymeric chains are depicted in Figure b.

elements.content: 2 has the identical molecular formula and chemical components as 1; however, the coordination environments at Cu(II) centers and the packing are somewhat different. The Cu(II) ions adopts 4+2 coordination geometry in 1, but has 4+1 coordination geometry in 2 with two water molecules in the lattice. The average in-plane bond distance of Cu1 in 1 agrees well with that in 2. But it is significantly shorter than for Cu2 as opposed to that of 1. This is due to the stronger bonding compensation for the lower coordination number in 2. The stereochemistry at N and chiral C, namely, C S N R is the same in both the ligands. Furthermore, there is significant difference in the crystal packing between 1 and 2. 2 does not have void, which can be accessed by solvent molecules; however 1, has cavities of 87 Å3, and that is 3.1% of the unit cell volume. In other words, packing efficiency in 2 is better than in 1 and reflected in the higher calculated density shown in Table .

elements.content: A close examination of the two 1D polymers 1 and 2 revealed that the difference in the coordination sphere has resulted in two different packing of 1D polymers. The C9−O3−Cu2 [x + 1/2, 1/2 − y, 1 − z] angle 163.1(8)° in 1 indicates that the two adjacent dimers are almost perpendicular to each other. However, the repeating dimers in 2 are arranged nearly parallel with the C9−O3−Cu2 [x, y + 1, z] angle 108.5(3)°. As a result, the idealized conformation in 1 is a 21 screw axis, while the repeating units are propagated by the translational symmetry in 2.

elements.content: The aqua ligand and carboxylato O atom attached to Cu(II) atoms on the same side of the Cu2O2 plane are linked by H−O−H···O−C hydrogen bonds. The same aqua ligand is linked to a lattice water molecule through H−O(7)−H···O(8) hydrogen bond. Further, this particular lattice water molecule forms a strong hydrogen bond to another lattice water molecule through O(8)−H···O(9). The oxygen atom of the lattice water is further hydrogen bonded to NH group from adjacent polymeric chain with O(9)···H−N. Furthermore, the two hydrogen atoms of this water molecule H−O(9)−H formed two more hydrogen bonds, with both carbonyl O(9)−H···O(3) and carboxylato O atoms O(9)−H···O(2) from the same polymeric chain. Finally, three hydrogen bonds were formed between this water molecule and the adjacent dimers, and as a result hydrogen-bonded double-stranded coordination polymeric structure has resulted. Consequently, the N−H protons are not participating in the complementary N−H···OC hydrogen bonding as observed in 1.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O)] n ·0.5 n C 3 -H 7 OH, 3. The single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction of 3 have been crystallized “[Cu2(Sval)2]” from 2-propanol. The complex 3 has an infinite 1D polymeric structure made up of dimeric building blocks as in 1 and 2. However, there are two crystallographically independent dimers in the asymmetric unit. The metal centers of these two dimers in the asymmetric unit have the same coordination geometry but slightly different bond distances and conformations (Figure ). All the four Cu(II) centers adopt a 4+1 square pyramidal coordination geometry and the angular parameter τ value of the four Cu(II) centers are 0.10, 0.09, 0.07, and 0.31. The tridentate ligands coordinate to the Cu(II) centers in the usual manner. Among the four Cu(II) centers, the apical positions of Cu1 and Cu3 are occupied by aqua ligands (Cu1−O13, 2.361(5) and Cu3−O14, 2.365(5) Å). The other two Cu(II) atoms form coordination bonds to carboxylato oxygen atoms from the adjacent dimers with Cu2−O9, 2.483(4) Å and Cu4−O3 (x, y, 1 + z), 2.372(4) Å.

elements.content: The water molecules and the ligand carboxylato O atoms attached to Cu(II) atoms are at the same side of the Cu2O2 plane as in 2, which leads to H−O−H···O hydrogen bonds. However, the relative orientations of the axial positions in the adjacent dimers are just opposite (Figure a) which results in a 1D coordination polymeric chain propagating along b-axis. Further the hydrogen atoms of the aqua ligands are hydrogen bonded to oxygen atoms of two different carboxylate groups from the neighboring dimers. The relative orientations between the adjacent dimeric building blocks in the polymers have been depicted by a schematic diagram in Figure b. The Cu−O−C angles adjoining the dimers are 128.7(4) and 130.0(3)°.

elements.content: The 1D polymer chains are arranged parallel to each other and further cross-linked by strong N−H···O−C hydrogen bonds to give hydrogen-bonded 2D network. It is interesting to note that in the absence of two “extra” water molecules in 3, the N−H hydrogen atoms are utilized for hydrogen bonding. The 2-propanol solvent molecules are partially trapped inside the lattice. Further, empty voids are present in the lattice with the cavity size of 65 Å3, which account for about 4% of unit cell volume.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [Cu 4 (Sval) 4 (H 2 O) 2 (C 4 H 9 OH)] n · n C 4 H 9 OH, 4. distinct dimeric units are present in the asymmetric unit of the complex [Cu4(Sval)4(H2O)2(C4H9OH)] n ·nC4H9OH, 4 as shown in Figure . The repeating tetrameric unit of the 1D polymer consists of two dimers and the coordination environments in each dimer are different. Specifically, Cu1 adopts 4+2 distorted octahedral sphere. The four basal positions of all Cu(II) centers are occupied by tridentate ligands and fifth apical position is occupied by an aqua ligand or oxygen atom of the carboxylate groups from the adjacent dimers. The Cu−O distances are as follows:  Cu1−O13, 2.463(8) Å, Cu2−O9 [x, y, 1 + z], 2.458(5) Å, Cu3−O14, 2.389(4) Å and Cu4−O3, 2.372(4) Å. The coordination geometry of Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 can thus be described as distorted square pyramidal as indicated by τ value, 0.09, 0.05, and 0.37, respectively. However, Cu1 adopts 4+2 distorted octahedral sphere with the final sixth position at Cu1 completed by the O atom of 1-butanol with Cu1−O1S, 2.468(7) Å.

elements.content: In all the structures of 1−4, a number of strong intra- and moderate intermolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonds have been observed which are very common in hydrogen-bonded coordination polymeric structures. Further, the C−H···O hydrogen bond distances fall in the range of strong hydrogen bonds, but we need to stress that the shorter distances are not necessarily stronger hydrogen bonds. The connectivity of the C−H···O bonds in these complexes does not give any interesting pattern in the presence of strong coordination and hydrogen bonds. Of these 3 shows an interesting C−H···π interaction (2.75 Å) between the ring containing the carbon atoms C31 to C36 and the methyl hydrogen atom H11E attached to C11D in the presence of several strong O−H···O hydrogen bonds. This bond does not appear to exist in 1 or 2. The presence of such C−H···π interactions may be uncertain in 4.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 showed a weight loss of 8.0% in the temperature range of 50−107 °C, corresponding to the complete loss of three molecules of water per dimer (expected weight loss 8.7%). However, the DTG curve of 1 revealed that there is another 0.9% weight loss in the temperature range of 136−162 °C. On the contrary, the TG of 2 indicated a single-step thermal dehydration with a weight loss of 8.2% at relatively low-temperature range of 50−90 °C (expected weight loss 8.7%) as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Since all three water molecules in 1 are coordinated to Cu(II) ions, it is expected that complete water loss should only happen above 150 °C. However, the TG curve of 1 indicated 90% of water loss under 100 °C, and dehydration is completed only at 160 °C. A closer look at the packing of 1 appears to indicate that the dehydration might lead to the cross-linking of 1D polymers due to the formation of new Cu−O(carboxylate) bonds and closing of channels in which partial water molecules might have trapped below 120 °C. These water molecules have been released at higher temperatures. This behavior is reminiscent of the DTG observed in [Zn2(Rsala)2(H2O)2]·2H2O. An examination of the crystal packing of 2 indicates that such formation of cavities is not possible. Therefore, 2 loses all three water molecules (one coordinated and two lattice water molecules) below 110 °C in a single-step. Unfortunately, we are unable to grow the single crystals of the dehydrated “[Cu2(Sval)2] n ” as it picks up solvent during crystallization.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of 3 shows a weight loss of 12.2% in the temperature range 60−150 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water and one molecule of 2-propanol per dimer (expected weight loss 12.2%). The TG curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 19.7% in the temperature range 90−160 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water and one molecule of 1-butanol (expected weight loss 18.4%). Both DTG curves of 3 and 4 indicated partially resolved two-step thermal dehydration patterns. The first step might correspond to the loss of water molecules and the second step due to 2-propanol (bp 82 °C) or 1-butanol (bp 118 °C). The TG curve of 4 showed a relatively higher temperature range til 160 °C because the solvent molecules are coordinated to Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: Building of chiral materials from achiral building components is an interesting challenge in materials science. Another alternative but practical approach is to employ simple and easily available chiral precursors. In this context compounds 1−4 nicely exemplify the feasibility of such approach. The removal of all three coordinated water molecules at ∼110 °C in 1 prompted us to crystallize the anhydrous 1 under various experimental conditions to isolate the anhydrous or dehydrated single crystals, which was expected to exhibit interesting multidimensional network structure. Instead, recrystallization of thermally dehydrated 1 in water leads to interesting supramolecular isomer 2. When the solvent was changed to 2-propanol or 1-butanol, two more 1D polymers 3 and 4 were formed as pseudo-supramolecular isomers instead of anhydrous complexes. The results are summarized in Scheme .
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Building of chiral materials from achiral building components is an interesting challenge in materials science. Another alternative but practical approach is to employ simple and easily available chiral precursors. In this context compounds 1-4 nicely exemplify the feasibility of such approach. The removal of all three coordinated water molecules at ~110 °C in 1 prompted us to crystallize the anhydrous 1 under various experimental conditions to isolate the anhydrous or dehydrated single crystals, which was expected to exhibit interesting multidimensional network structure. Instead, recrystallization of thermally dehydrated 1 in water leads to interesting supramolecular isomer 2. When the solvent was changed to 2-propanol or 1-butanol, two more 1D polymers 3 and 4 were formed as pseudo-supramolecular isomers instead of anhydrous complexes. The results are summarized in Scheme .

elements.content: Most of the conformational isomers the coordination spheres are identical. The present study shows four different conformations of the 1D polymer for varying first coordination sphere of the Cu(II) in the dimeric building block. 1 and 2 have identical chemical formula but entirely different coordination geometry at the metal centers; hence, packing structures as the coordination spheres of Cu(II) ions are also different due to water molecules. These are the true examples of structural supramolecular isomers. The packing of the 1D polymers in 3 and 4 are similar, but the building blocks are different as one of the Cu(II) ion in 4 is coordinated to 1-butanol so that the repeating unit is not the dimer but tetramer.
elements.clean_text: Most of the conformational isomers the coordination spheres are identical. The present study shows four different conformations of the 1D polymer for varying first coordination sphere of the Cu(II) in the dimeric building block. 1 and 2 have identical chemical formula but entirely different coordination geometry at the metal centers; hence, packing structures as the coordination spheres of Cu(II) ions are also different due to water molecules. These are the true examples of structural supramolecular isomers. The packing of the 1D polymers in 3 and 4 are similar, but the building blocks are different as one of the Cu(II) ion in 4 is coordinated to 1-butanol so that the repeating unit is not the dimer but tetramer.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of Ligands. H 2 Sval. To a solution of l-valine (10 mmol) in water (10 mL) containing KOH (56 mg, 10 mmol) was added salicyladehyde (120 mg, 10 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL). The yellow solution was stirred for 30 min at room temperature prior to cooling in ice bath. The intermediate Schiff base was reduced by an excess of sodium borohydride (46 mg, 12 mmol) solid. The yellow color discharged after a few minutes, and the solution was acidified by acetic acid to a pH of 5−6. The resulting solid was filtered off, washed with ethanol and then diethyl ether, and dried. Yield. 99 mg (49%); mp 225−227° C. Anal. Calcd for C12H17NO3 C, 64.57; H, 7.62; N, 6.28; found:  C, 64.32; H, 7.25; N, 6.49. 1H NMR (dmso-d 6):  δ 0.91(d, 6H, H10, H11), 2.00 (m, H, H9), 2.95 (d, H, H8) and 3.82 (AB system, 2H, J AB = 13.6 Hz, H7), 6.73−6.75 (m, 2H, H2, H5), 7.11−7.19 (m, 2H, H3, H4).

Synthesis of Complexes. [Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O) 3 ] n , 1. To a solution of H2Sval (208 mg, 1 mmol) and LiOH (28 mg, 2 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added copper(II) acetate monohydrate (200 mg, 1 mmol) in water (10 mL). The dark green solution was stirred for 10 min and filtered. Green long rodlike crystals formed form the filtrate in a few days. The crystals were separated by decantation and dried in air. Yield:  230 mg (37%); Anal. Calcd. for C24H36Cu2N2O9: C, 46.2; H, 5.8; N, 4.5. Found:  C, 45.7; H, 5.4; N, 4.4. UV−vis (Nujol, nm):  372 (CT) and 671(d−d transition). μB = 1.40 BM.

The anhydrous compound has been prepared by heating 1 at 115−120 °C for 2 h or 150 °C for 1 h.

[Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O)] n ·2 n H 2 O, 2. The dehydrated 1 was recrystallized from water to give colorless crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray structure analysis. Yield:  12.5 mg (20%); Anal. Calcd for C24H36Cu2N2O9: C, 46.2; H, 5.8; N, 4.5. Found:  C, 45.7; H, 5.4; N, 4.4. UV−vis (Nujol, nm):  361 (CT) and 656 (d−d transition). μB = 1.74 BM.

[Cu 2 (Sval) 2 (H 2 O)] n ·0.5 n C 3 H 7 OH, 3. The anhydrous 1 was recrystallized from 2-propanol to give colorless crystals suitable for X-ray structure analysis. Yield:  42 mg (34%). Anal. Calcd for C25.5H36Cu2N2O7.5:  C, 49.5; H, 5.8; N, 4.5. Found:  C, 49.3; H, 5.8; N, 4.1. UV−vis (Nujol, nm):  394 (CT) and 673 (d−d transition). μB = 1.75 BM.

[Cu 4 (Sval) 4 (H 2 O) 2 (C 4 H 9 OH)] n · n C 4 H 9 OH, 4. The dehydrated 1 was recrystallized from 1-butanol to get colorless crystals. Yield:  24 mg (37%). Anal. Calcd for C56H84Cu4N4O16: C, 50.8; H, 6.4; N, 4.2. Found:  C, 49.6; H, 6.0; N, 4.6. UV−vis (Nujol, nm):  371 (CT) and 686 (d−d transition). μB = 2.01 BM.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric Analysis. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 showed a weight loss of 8.0% in the temperature range of 50−107 °C, corresponding to the complete loss of three molecules of water per dimer (expected weight loss 8.7%). However, the DTG curve of 1 revealed that there is another 0.9% weight loss in the temperature range of 136−162 °C. On the contrary, the TG of 2 indicated a single-step thermal dehydration with a weight loss of 8.2% at relatively low-temperature range of 50−90 °C (expected weight loss 8.7%) as shown in Figure .

Since all three water molecules in 1 are coordinated to Cu(II) ions, it is expected that complete water loss should only happen above 150 °C. However, the TG curve of 1 indicated 90% of water loss under 100 °C, and dehydration is completed only at 160 °C. A closer look at the packing of 1 appears to indicate that the dehydration might lead to the cross-linking of 1D polymers due to the formation of new Cu−O(carboxylate) bonds and closing of channels in which partial water molecules might have trapped below 120 °C. These water molecules have been released at higher temperatures. This behavior is reminiscent of the DTG observed in [Zn2(Rsala)2(H2O)2]·2H2O. An examination of the crystal packing of 2 indicates that such formation of cavities is not possible. Therefore, 2 loses all three water molecules (one coordinated and two lattice water molecules) below 110 °C in a single-step. Unfortunately, we are unable to grow the single crystals of the dehydrated “[Cu2(Sval)2] n ” as it picks up solvent during crystallization.

Thermogravimetric analysis of 3 shows a weight loss of 12.2% in the temperature range 60−150 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water and one molecule of 2-propanol per dimer (expected weight loss 12.2%). The TG curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 19.7% in the temperature range 90−160 °C, corresponding to one molecule of water and one molecule of 1-butanol (expected weight loss 18.4%). Both DTG curves of 3 and 4 indicated partially resolved two-step thermal dehydration patterns. The first step might correspond to the loss of water molecules and the second step due to 2-propanol (bp 82 °C) or 1-butanol (bp 118 °C). The TG curve of 4 showed a relatively higher temperature range til 160 °C because the solvent molecules are coordinated to Cu(II) ions.
